bibl.title: Letter from John W. Hart to Philip Showalter Hench, June 18, 1942

div1.p: Hart refers Hench to men associated with the yellow fever experiments and to publications about the experiments.

div1.head: Letter from John W. Hart to Philip Showalter Hench, June 18, 1942
div1.opener:
WINTHROP PRODUCTS, INC.
170 VARICK STREET
NEW YORK, N. Y.
June 18, 1942
P. O. BOX 90
CANAL ST. STATION
CABLE ADDRESS
“W I N C O X”
Dr. Philip Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Supplementing my previous letter concerning
the Colonel's leaves, you no doubt will be interested to
learn that I had a rather lengthy discussion with Doctor Stock-
man of the Winthrop Chemical Company regarding your talk in
Atlantic City.

Several points of interest were given me by
Doctor Stockman which -- although I assume you have them on
file -- I am communicating to you.

The doctor informs me that the annual edition
of the U. S. Army Register, by Act of Congress, includes a
“Roll of Honor” in which are given the names, addresses and
pertinent data concerning all those persons who were connect-
ed with the yellow fever investigation. This list includes
the name of Doctor Robert Page Cook of Lexington, Va., who
was one of the group who exposed themselves to feedings by
the infected mosquito. He is still alive and, according to
the American Medical Association, is the Health Officer of
Lexington, Va.

Doctor Stockman also informed me that
Doctor Rudolph Matas of New Orleans, whom you probably know,
worked with yellow fever in the early eighties and was a very
close friend of Agramonte. Furthermore, he called my atten-
tion to a book published in 1920 and 1921 by the A.M.A.: “Bio-
graphy of George M. Sternberg”-- and cited the Sternberg
theory of a yellow fever bacillus, which was heartily support-
ed by old Dean Kober of Georgetown University.

You also would be interested in the book,
“Death Loses a Pair of Wings” by Robert Lamson, published by
Scribner in 1939, in which great credit is given to Gorgas.

At the time of the printing of the Walter Reed
Stamp, this organization sent out First Day Covers. Unfortu-
nately, I do not have one of the stamps, but I am enclosing the
envelope together with the literature which accompanied this
First Day Cover.

With kind personal regards to Mrs. Hench and yourself,
I am,
div1.closer:
Cordially yours, John W. Hart Just read your letter. Have just been made V. President of Winthrop Products -
so - wear the leaves for both of us. Looking forward to
that book's tour of Cuba! Swell!!!
Yours for mas grande casas y
mas pequeno arboles
Hart
